passages.text: EQUITY:PHARMACEUTICALS

Zydus acquires Comfort Click to foray into VMS in the UK and Europe Zydus Lifesciences' subsidiary, Zydus Wellness, announced on 29 August 2025 the acquisition of \(100\%\) stake in Comfort Click Limited (unlisted), a UK based digital consumer healthcare platform for a consideration of GBP239mn. The company primarily has a presence in the Vitamins, Minerals and Supplements (VMS) segment. Comfort Click has a presence in \(\sim 13\) countries, with operations across the UK and Europe. It plans to expand into the US in the near term, according to the company. The company caters to adult, paediatric and animal health segments, with a diversified product portfolio consisting of three major brands - WeightWorld, Maxmedix and Animigo. WeightWorld includes plant- based supplements, vitamins and minerals, collagen, omegas, probiotics and micronutrients and sports nutrition for adults. Maxmedix is a specialty VMS gummy brand catering to paediatric nutritional requirements. Animigo is a natural pet VMS brand with a range of pet care products. The company operates through an e- commerce and direct- to- consumer (D2C) model. Nehal Patel and Huzefa Motorwala are currently the CEO and COO of the company. Nehal has experience of \(\sim 20\) years in the consumer and healthcare businesses and has been with the company since 2023. Huzefa joined Comfort Click in 2007 and has risen through the ranks and has been working as the COO of the company since 2024. Zydus has announced that the existing management team will continue to lead the operations.
We think the acquisition of Comfort Click by Zydus Wellness serves two primary objectives:

a. Expansion of the product basket: Zydus Wellness is currently present in consumer health areas, such as: a) low sugar, protein snacking and energy categories with a leadership position in sugar substitutes in India with its SugarFree brands, b) skincare products like Nyet and EverYuth, and c) nutrition related products with its Naturell (RiteBite) portfolio. Comfort Click's acquisition provides the company an entry into the Vitamins, Minerals and Supplements (VMS) segment. The VMS market in Europe is currently estimated at GBP11bn (~USD15bn), and is expected to reach USD 50-60bn globally by 2030, as per management. 
b. Geographic diversification: Zydus Wellness' major international markets currently are Africa, the Middle East, SE Asia and Aus/NZ, with \(\sim 85\%\) of international revenue coming from the top-5 markets. Zydus Wellness had previously (1QFY26 earnings call) indicated its aim to increase contribution from international revenue in consolidated revenue to \(\sim 8 - 10\%\) in the next 4-5 years, from \(\sim 3 - 4\%\) currently. With the acquisition of Comfort Click, Zydus Wellness plans to increase its global footprint with entry into developed markets like the UK and Europe and further expansion into the US. We think the company may further intend to bring in the Comfort Click brands into India, amplifying its consumer care offerings in India.
It appears to us that Comfort Click will operate independently and there are no plans at this stage to integrate the operations with Zydus Wellness' current business.
Rating RemainsBuyTarget price RemainsINR 1,140Closing price 29 August 2025INR 981
India Pharmaceuticals

Zydus Wellness believes the acquisition will be cash EPS accretive. Comfort Click recorded revenue of GBP134mn in FY25 (June- ended) with a five- year revenue CAGR of \(\sim 57\%\) (FY23- 25 CAGR was \(\sim 60\%\) ), driven by the launch of innovative and new- age products, as per management. For FY25 (June- ended), the company recorded an EBITDA of GBP21mn, which implies an acquisition value of \(\sim 1.8x\) EV/sales and \(\sim 11.4x\) EV/EBITDA on FY25 sales and EBITDA, respectively. Furthermore, we estimate Comfort Click's T12M June 2025 revenue/EBITDA would be \(\sim 54\% /61\%\) of Zydus Wellness T12M June 2025 revenue/EBITDA, and \(\sim 6\% /3\%\) of Zydus Lifesciences consolidated revenue/EBITDA for T12M June 2025.

The details regarding the financing of the acquisition are yet to be disclosed by the company. Zydus Wellness turned net- cash- positive as of June 2025, as per management. However, the acquisition cost of GBP239mn ( \(\sim \text{INR} 26,328\text{mn}\) ), if funded through debt would lead net debt- to- EBITDA at \(\sim 4.3x\) debt on the combined T12M June 2025 EBITDA of Zydus Wellness and Comfort Click. Zydus Wellness may sustain the high level of debt given that it is a cash generating business and has support of the parent Zydus Lifesciences. Zydus Lifesciences, has net cash balance of INR56.3bn as of June 2025.

Zydus Lifesciences has stepped up business development and partnershipsZydus Lifesciences has been aggressive in acquiring newer assets and venturing into newer initiatives through inorganic routes. The company has made investments in medtech and specialty businesses, along with expanding its consumer portfolio. The key deals in the recent past are highlighted in Fig. 3. The strategy of rapid inorganic expansion and diversification may present execution challenges, in our view. Investors in the past have expressed concerns around such a diversified presence. We think it would be critical to ensure that the company invests and expands management's bandwidth.

We have a Buy rating for the stock ZYDUSLIF IN. Our March 2026 target price of INR1,140 is based on 30x FY27F EPS ex- key products of INR38.0. Key products include gRevlimid, gMyrbetriq, glbrance tablets, Sitaqlipin 505b(2) and gAdempas. Our valuation multiple is supported by: 1) growth of domestic businesses, which we expect to contribute \(\sim 44\%\) of EBITDA in FY27F; 2) investments in specialty and vaccines that are likely to contribute materially beyond FY27F; and 3) a strong balance sheet that presents scope for growth through value- accretive acquisitions. The stock currently trades at \(22.5x / 22.7x\) FY26/27F EPS of INR43.5/43.2.
Fig. 1: Zydus Wellness – expanding the product basket
Source: Company data, Nomura research
Fig. 2: Zydus Wellness – geo-diversification
Source: Company data, Nomura research
Fig. 3: Zydus group - recent acquisitions

Theacquired brands Ritebite and Ritebite Max Protein were fast growing with high double-digitgrowthINR 3900mn3.3Mar-25Amplitude SurgicalAcquired 85.6% stake in the company, which is a leading player in the global market forsurgical technologies for lower limb orthopaedics. The company develops and marketshigh-end products for orthopaedic surgery, primarily covering the main pathologiesaffecting the hip and knee.EUR 257mn2.8Jun-25AgenusAcquired two US-based biologics manufacturing facilities with combined bioreactorcapacity of ~8kL from Agenus Inc. to foray into the global biologics CDMO business.USD 141mnAug-25Comfort ClickZydus Wellness acquired a Vitamins, Minerals and Supplements portfolio with majorbrands: WeightWorld, maxmedix and Animigo, with market presence in UK and EuropeGBP 239mn1.8Specialty AssetsZydus, through its subsidiary Sentynl Therapeutics has acquired three major assets -CUTX-101 in February 2021, Nullbry in March 2022, and Zokinvy in March 2024. a) CUTX-101, a copper histidine injection, is used for the treatment of Menkes disease, which is a rare genetic paediatric disease caused by a gene mutation. b) Nullbry is used to treat ultra-rare, a life-threatening disease molybdenum cofactor deficiency (MoCD) Type A. Theproduct was approved by the USFDA in 2021 as the first medicine to treat the condition. c)Zokinvy is approved in the US for treatment of Progeria, an ultra rare disease that leads topremature aging.CUTX (USD20mn +milestone and royaltypayments); Nullbry (notdisclosed); Zokinvy(USD45.2mn)
Source: Company data, Nomura research

Valuation Methodology We arrive at target price of INR1,140 based on 30x FY27 EPS ex gkey products of INR38.0. The key products include gRevlimid, gMyrbetiq, glbrance tabs, Sitaglipitn 505b(2) and gAdempas. The benchmark index for the stock is Nifty 50.

Risks that may impede the achievement of the target price Key downside risks: a) higher the estimated pricing pressure in key markets of US and India; b) regulatory delays in product approvals; c) adverse currency movements, d) Steep rise in investments in high risk segments (eg: innovation research, specialty); e) slower than estimated growth in India
